meta.title: RWAV Operational Playbook 2026-2030
meta.subtitle: Detailed Implementation Guidance for Strategic Transformation
meta.author: Carlorbiz Strategic Consulting
meta.description: Comprehensive operational details, stakeholder recommendations, risk management, governance, and implementation protocols

overview.methodology: One-on-one structured interviews, thematic analysis, cross-validation with survey data

keyFindings.organisation: Royal Australian College of General Practitioners (RACGP)
keyFindings.keyQuote: RWAV is the organisation that can bring everyone together without territorial competition—that's invaluable in this fragmented sector.
mainRecommendations: Develop unified supervisor support frameworks across all training organisations
Create shared data platforms for workforce planning and coordination
Establish regional workforce planning collaboratives with RACGP participation
Coordinate GP-specific retention strategies with other specialties
keyFindings.resourceImplications: Medium - requires partnership development and platform investment

keyFindings.keyQuote: Rural emergency medicine needs champions who understand both the clinical demands and community context—RWAV can be that bridge.
mainRecommendations: Develop emergency medicine-specific rural pathways and rotation programs
Implement technology-enabled mentoring for isolated emergency physicians
Create cross-specialty training coordination (ED, anaesthetics, rural generalist)
Support rural emergency department workforce planning

keyFindings.keyQuote: Practice managers are the unsung heroes of rural health—investing in their capacity strengthens the entire system.
mainRecommendations: Develop rural-specific practice management certification programs
Create shared administrative service models for small practices
Provide technology and systems support for rural practices
Establish practice manager peer networks and professional development

keyFindings.keyQuote: PHNs and RWAs need to stop duplicating efforts and start genuinely collaborating—shared data is the foundation.
mainRecommendations: Establish formal PHN-RWAV data sharing agreements and protocols
Create joint advocacy frameworks for state and Commonwealth engagement
Develop collaborative workforce planning processes at regional level
Co-design and co-fund supervision and retention programs
keyFindings.resourceImplications: Low - primarily partnership and protocol development

keyFindings.keyQuote: Cross-border coordination is essential but rarely happens—RWAV could be the glue that makes it work.
mainRecommendations: Develop cross-jurisdictional service coordination models for border regions
Create shared workforce intelligence across NSW-VIC border
Implement technology-enabled support for isolated border communities
Establish community partnership models that cross state boundaries
keyFindings.resourceImplications: Medium - requires interstate negotiation and partnership

keyFindings.keyQuote: Evidence-based advocacy wins policy change—RWAV needs comprehensive evaluation frameworks to demonstrate outcomes.
mainRecommendations: Develop rigorous evaluation frameworks for workforce interventions
Create pilot programs demonstrating alternative funding models
Build Commonwealth-compatible data systems for policy influence
Establish evidence-based advocacy capacity within RWAV
keyFindings.resourceImplications: Medium - evaluation and data expertise required

keyFindings.keyQuote: Universities can be partners, not just training providers—research collaboration strengthens both sectors.
mainRecommendations: Establish research partnerships for workforce innovation
Develop community-based training models in pilot regions
Create student support frameworks for rural placements
Implement PhD and research collaborations on rural workforce

keyFindings.keyQuote: Patient journey-led planning, not organisational silos, should drive rural health workforce strategy.
mainRecommendations: Design workforce planning around patient pathways, not professional groups
Develop shared KPIs across universities, health services, and RWAV
Create multidisciplinary co-design processes for training programs
Establish regional workforce planning collaboratives with university participation

keyFindings.keyQuote: Scholarships need reform—longer rural placements, expanded internships, and genuine community integration.
mainRecommendations: Reform scholarship programs to incentivise longer rural placements
Expand rural internship and residency programs
Develop high school engagement pipelines for rural health careers
Create local specialist training pathways to retain rural-origin students
keyFindings.resourceImplications: High - requires funding model changes and partnerships

keyFindings.keyQuote: Data and evidence-backed innovation is how we transform rural medical education—partnership for research is key.
mainRecommendations: Develop data-driven approaches to rural training placement optimisation
Create PhD collaboration opportunities on rural workforce innovation
Implement evidence-based retention interventions in training pipeline
Establish longitudinal tracking of rural training outcomes
keyFindings.resourceImplications: Medium - research capacity and data systems

keyFindings.keyQuote: Cultural safety must be embedded from day one, not retrofitted—ACCHO leadership is non-negotiable.
mainRecommendations: Implement mandatory cultural safety training for all rural health professionals
Ensure ACCHO leadership in all First Nations workforce initiatives
Develop Indigenous-led mentoring and supervision frameworks
Create culturally safe onboarding processes for all rural placements
keyFindings.resourceImplications: Medium - training development and ACCHO partnership

keyFindings.keyQuote: Supervisor coordination and accreditation streamlining would transform rural training capacity.
mainRecommendations: Coordinate supervision resources across all training organisations
Streamline supervisor accreditation processes across colleges
Develop cultural mentoring programs for supervisors
Create technology-enabled supervision support systems

keyFindings.keyQuote: Nursing and midwifery pathways need as much attention as medical—it's the same coordination challenges.
mainRecommendations: Extend coordination models to nursing and midwifery training
Develop nurse practitioner rural pathways and support
Create midwifery-specific retention and recruitment strategies
Establish allied health coordination frameworks

keyFindings.keyQuote: Scale best-practice cultural mentoring universally—every Indigenous placement needs this foundation.
mainRecommendations: Scale cultural mentoring programs across all Indigenous health settings
Develop universal ACCHO-led onboarding for rural health workforce
Create Indigenous workforce development pathways with community control
Implement community-controlled evaluation of all cultural safety initiatives
keyFindings.resourceImplications: Medium-High - ACCHO partnership and program scaling

keyFindings.keyQuote: Family support services and innovative employment models are essential for extreme rural contexts.
mainRecommendations: Develop comprehensive family support services for remote practitioners
Implement technology-enabled specialist consultation models
Create innovative employment models (job sharing, part-time, rotational)
Establish hub-and-spoke coordination for remote service delivery
keyFindings.resourceImplications: High - requires service model innovation and funding

keyFindings.organisation: Services for Australian Rural and Remote Allied Health (SARRAH)
keyFindings.keyQuote: Allied health needs profession-specific solutions, not medical model adaptations.
mainRecommendations: Develop allied health-specific coordination frameworks and platforms
Create allied health professional development and supervision networks
Implement technology platforms supporting allied health service delivery
Establish allied health workforce data collection and intelligence

keyFindings.keyQuote: RWAV's evolution requires strategic flexibility, sustained community engagement, and strong governance.
mainRecommendations: Maintain strategic flexibility to adapt to changing rural contexts
Sustain deep community engagement through transformation
Develop regional collaboration frameworks that respect local autonomy
Build governance capacity for increased organisational complexity
keyFindings.resourceImplications: Medium - governance and change management capacity

keyFindings.keyQuote: Community and family integration is the key to retention—professional networking alone isn't enough.
mainRecommendations: Develop comprehensive family integration support programs
Create spouse/partner employment assistance services
Establish children's education support and connection services
Build professional and social networking opportunities
keyFindings.resourceImplications: High - requires cross-sector partnerships beyond health

keyFindings.keyQuote: Join VHA's health collective for risk-shared advocacy—sector-wide narrative, not individual organisational risk.
mainRecommendations: Join VHA health collective to participate in sector-level advocacy
Engage in high-level sector needs advocacy without direct political confrontation
Build narrative-driven advocacy campaigns through collective voice
Share advocacy risk across sector participants

objectives: Influence at least 5 major rural health workforce policy reforms by 2030
Establish RWAV as trusted policy advisor to state and Commonwealth governments
Build evidence base for systemic rural health workforce reform
Lead coalition-based advocacy for sector transformation
overview.approach: Evidence-based, coalition-led, narrative-driven advocacy that minimises political risk for government-funded entity

priorityReforms.title: Integrated Rural Health Workforce Planning Framework
priorityReforms.description: Commonwealth-State agreement on coordinated rural health workforce planning using shared data platforms
priorityReforms.advocacyStrategy: Evidence demonstration through Community Map pilot, PHN partnership validation, Commonwealth Department engagement

priorityReforms.title: Funding Model Reform for Rural Coordination
priorityReforms.description: Alternative funding models that recognise and resource coordination as legitimate health system function
priorityReforms.advocacyStrategy: Pilot program demonstration, economic analysis of coordination ROI, VHA collective advocacy

priorityReforms.title: Streamlined Supervisor Accreditation
priorityReforms.description: Cross-college harmonisation of rural supervisor accreditation reducing administrative burden
priorityReforms.advocacyStrategy: College partnership demonstration, supervisor burden analysis, unified standards proposal

priorityReforms.title: Cultural Safety Mandate in Rural Health Funding
priorityReforms.description: Mandatory ACCHO partnership and cultural safety requirements for all Commonwealth rural health funding
priorityReforms.advocacyStrategy: ACCHO-led advocacy, evidence from pilot implementation, alignment with Closing the Gap commitments

priorityReforms.title: Technology-Enabled Rural Service Delivery Framework
priorityReforms.description: Policy and funding frameworks supporting technology-enabled rural health service delivery and supervision
priorityReforms.advocacyStrategy: Innovation demonstration, technology ROI analysis, telehealth expansion advocacy

advocacyCapabilities.evidenceGeneration: Community Map data, pilot evaluation findings, stakeholder testimonials, economic analysis
advocacyCapabilities.coalitionBuilding: VHA membership, Rural Health Alliance Victoria, stakeholder advisory council, sector working groups
advocacyCapabilities.governmentEngagement: Regular briefings to health departments, Commonwealth submission processes, ministerial advisory participation
advocacyCapabilities.mediaStrategy: Strategic media partnerships, case study publication, thought leadership articles, sector conference presentations

framework.approach: Proactive identification, assessment, mitigation, and monitoring with Board-level oversight
framework.reviewCadence: Quarterly risk register review, annual comprehensive risk assessment, incident-triggered reviews
framework.escalationProtocol: Operational risks → CEO → Transformation Oversight Committee → Board (for strategic/critical risks)

risks.description: Insufficient community buy-in or engagement fatigue
mitigationStrategies: Intensive relationship building in pilot regions before formal launch
Clear value demonstration through early wins and visible outcomes
Flexible engagement approaches adapted to community preferences
Community co-design of engagement processes
Regular feedback loops and responsive adaptation
contingencyPlans: Pause expansion until community confidence rebuilt

mitigationStrategies: Early and transparent communication of transformation rationale
Individual stakeholder engagement to understand concerns
Co-design of coordination mechanisms with stakeholders
Demonstration of mutual benefit and win-win outcomes
Gradual implementation with stakeholder feedback integration
contingencyPlans: Modify coordination model based on feedback
Demonstrate early value through quick wins

risks.description: Platform development delays or functionality limitations
mitigationStrategies: Agile development methodology with iterative releases
User feedback integration at every sprint
Alternative solution preparation (manual coordination processes)
Experienced technology partner selection with proven rural health expertise
Clear requirements definition with stakeholder input
Buffer time built into implementation timeline
contingencyPlans: Reduce platform scope to core functions

risks.description: Data security breach or privacy violation
mitigationStrategies: Comprehensive security architecture design and independent audit
Strict access controls and user authentication
Encryption of data in transit and at rest
Regular security testing and vulnerability assessment
Privacy impact assessment and ongoing monitoring
Staff training on data security and privacy obligations
Incident response plan development and regular testing

risks.description: Revenue stream validation failure or market resistance
mitigationStrategies: Conservative revenue projections with multiple scenarios
Multiple revenue stream testing to diversify risk
Government funding backup maintained during transition period
Early market testing and client development
Flexible pricing and service models responsive to market feedback
Regular financial monitoring and early intervention triggers
Transparent communication with government funders about transformation
Evidence demonstration of improved outcomes and value
Multiple-year funding agreements where possible
Contingency reserves for funding fluctuations
Alternative government funding source development

risks.description: Inadequate First Nations partnership or cultural protocol failures
mitigationStrategies: ACCHO leadership priority in all First Nations initiatives
Comprehensive cultural safety training for all staff and Board
Community-controlled evaluation processes
Regular cultural safety audits and feedback
Dedicated cultural safety advisor with authority
Embedding cultural safety in all policies and procedures
Continuous learning and improvement culture

risks.description: Transformation pace exceeds organisational change capacity
mitigationStrategies: Phased implementation with adequate preparation time
Change management capacity building
Regular staff wellbeing and capacity assessment
External change management expertise where needed
Realistic timeline expectations and buffer periods

risks.description: Loss of key staff or leadership during transformation
mitigationStrategies: Succession planning for critical roles
Knowledge documentation and transfer processes
Competitive retention strategies
Positive organisational culture development
Clear career pathways and development opportunities
First-mover advantage through rapid pilot implementation
Strong stakeholder relationship maintenance
Continuous innovation and value demonstration
Strategic partnership development
Brand positioning and thought leadership

board.role: Strategic direction, transformation oversight, major decision approval, risk governance, CEO accountability
board.composition: Independent directors with health, community, First Nations, business, and governance expertise
board.meetingFrequency: Bi-monthly regular meetings, additional transformation update sessions
keyResponsibilities: Approve strategic plan and transformation direction
Oversee transformation progress and risk management
Approve major partnerships and financial commitments
Monitor organisational performance against strategic objectives
Ensure cultural safety and ACCHO partnership integrity
CEO performance management and succession planning

transformationOversightCommittee.role: Board-level monitoring of strategic transformation progress and risk
transformationOversightCommittee.composition: Board Chair, 2-3 Board members, CEO, Transformation Program Director
keyResponsibilities: Review transformation risks and mitigation effectiveness
Oversee pilot program implementation and evaluation
Escalate critical issues to full Board
transformationOversightCommittee.reportingLines: Reports to full Board at each regular meeting

stakeholderAdvisoryCouncil.role: Representative body ensuring community and stakeholder accountability
stakeholderAdvisoryCouncil.composition: Representatives from PHNs, health services, training organisations, professional colleges, universities, community groups (15-20 members)
keyResponsibilities: Provide feedback on RWAV strategic direction and initiatives
Champion RWAV coordination role within own organisations
Contribute to partnership development and problem-solving
Participate in evaluation and continuous improvement
stakeholderAdvisoryCouncil.reportingLines: Advises CEO and Board, no formal authority but influential voice

accho PartnerhipCouncil.role: First Nations leadership in cultural safety governance and Indigenous workforce initiatives
accho PartnerhipCouncil.composition: Representatives from ACCHOs in each pilot region, First Nations health leaders, Indigenous health professionals (8-12 members)
accho PartnerhipCouncil.meetingFrequency: Bi-monthly meetings, co-design workshops as needed
keyResponsibilities: Lead cultural safety framework development and monitoring
Direct all First Nations workforce initiatives
Approve (or veto) any initiatives affecting Indigenous communities
Conduct community-controlled evaluation of cultural safety
Advise Board on First Nations strategic priorities
accho PartnerhipCouncil.reportingLines: Direct line to Board on cultural safety matters, authority over Indigenous initiatives
accho PartnerhipCouncil.specialProvisions: Veto power on cultural safety decisions, community-controlled evaluation mandate

pilotRegionSteeringGroups.role: Local governance for community-centred pilot implementation
pilotRegionSteeringGroups.composition: Community representatives, local health services, ACCHO partners, training providers, local government (8-12 members per region)
keyResponsibilities: Guide pilot implementation in local context
Provide feedback for statewide model refinement
pilotRegionSteeringGroups.reportingLines: Reports to CEO and Transformation Oversight Committee

acchoPartnershipCouncil: Veto on initiatives affecting Indigenous communities

reportingFramework.board: Quarterly Board papers with strategic progress, financial performance, risk register, stakeholder feedback, transformation milestones
reportingFramework.transformationOversightCommittee: Monthly transformation dashboard with milestone status, risk heatmap, budget vs actual, key issues
reportingFramework.stakeholderAdvisoryCouncil: Quarterly stakeholder report with engagement summary, partnership status, pilot progress, feedback themes
reportingFramework.acchoPartnershipCouncil: Bi-monthly cultural safety report with ACCHO satisfaction, cultural safety audit findings, First Nations workforce outcomes, community feedback
reportingFramework.publicReporting: Annual public report with transformation progress, outcomes achieved, stakeholder testimonials, financial summary

overview.approach: Structured change management aligned with transformation phases, emphasising communication, capability building, and cultural evolution

staffImpact: Role changes from direct service to coordination focus
New skills required (data analytics, partnership facilitation, technology use)
Increased complexity and scope of work
Potential anxiety about revenue diversification and sustainability
stakeholderImpact: Shift from RWAV as competitor to RWAV as collaborator
Changed engagement models and communication channels
Potential for improved outcomes and efficiency
culturalImpact: From service delivery to strategic leadership mindset
From government dependency to entrepreneurial thinking
From individual organisation to collective sector view
Enhanced cultural safety and First Nations partnership

internal.frequency: Weekly updates during intensive phases, fortnightly in consolidation phases
keyMessages: Why transformation is necessary (coordination crisis, stakeholder mandate)
What success looks like (vision and outcomes)
How we'll get there (phased approach, pilot testing)
What it means for staff (roles, development, support)
How staff can contribute (feedback, ideas, participation)

external.frequency: Monthly external updates, quarterly stakeholder briefings, annual public report
keyMessages: Pilot program approach and early wins
targetAudiences: Stakeholder organisations (PHNs, health services, colleges, universities)
Communities (pilot regions and broader rural Victoria)

leadershipDevelopment.focus: Transformation governance, strategic risk management, complex stakeholder landscapes
leadershipDevelopment.format: Board education sessions, external expert input, peer learning

leadershipDevelopment.focus: Transformation execution, change leadership, strategic partnership development
leadershipDevelopment.format: Executive coaching, leadership programs, action learning

leadershipDevelopment.focus: Leading teams through change, operational excellence, stakeholder engagement
leadershipDevelopment.format: Management development programs, peer networks, mentoring

successCelebration.approach: Regular recognition of milestones, early wins, and individual contributions
mechanisms: Staff recognition awards for transformation contributions
Success stories shared in newsletters and meetings
Public acknowledgement of stakeholder partnership contributions

overview.purpose: Multi-organisational coordination centres addressing workforce retention through comprehensive support
overview.targetAudience: Rural health professionals at all career stages, particularly mid-career practitioners

activities: Identify partner organisations (health services, PHNs, training providers, professional colleges)
Conduct stakeholder mapping and readiness assessment
Develop partnership agreements and MoUs with clear roles and responsibilities
Establish hub steering committee with partner representation
Define retention challenges and priority cohorts for initial focus
Secure commitment of in-kind and financial resources from partners
Design hub governance structure and decision-making processes
Develop retention program menu (mentorship, peer support, family services, professional development)
Create practitioner onboarding process and welcome package
Establish communication channels and engagement platforms
Recruit hub coordinator and support staff
Set up physical space (if applicable) or virtual hub infrastructure
Launch hub with stakeholder event and practitioner invitation
Enroll practitioners into hub membership and conduct needs assessment
Match practitioners with mentors, peer groups, and support services
Deliver initial programs (mentorship kickoff, professional development, family orientation)
Establish regular touchpoints and engagement rhythm
Monitor engagement levels and adjust program delivery
Expand program offerings based on practitioner feedback
Develop specialised programs for specific cohorts (IMGs, mid-career, new graduates)
Integrate Community Map data for targeted retention interventions
Build family support services (spousal employment, education, community connection)
Strengthen multi-disciplinary collaboration and cross-sector partnerships
Conduct comprehensive evaluation (retention outcomes, practitioner satisfaction, partner value)
Document best practices and lessons learned
Develop hub replication toolkit for other regions
Present findings to Board and stakeholders for scaling decision
Plan statewide rollout based on pilot evidence

successMetrics: 15% improvement in retention rates for hub-enrolled practitioners vs non-enrolled
85%+ partner organisation satisfaction with hub value
Practitioner utilisation rate >60% (enrolled practitioners actively using services)
criticalSuccessFactors: Strong partner commitment and in-kind contributions
Dedicated hub coordinator with relationship-building skills
Responsive program design adapting to practitioner feedback
Integration with Community Map for data-driven interventions
Family-inclusive approach recognising retention is household decision

overview.purpose: Real-time workforce intelligence system providing early warning, strategic planning, and coordination capability
overview.scope: Statewide coverage of all rural health workforce categories, integrated with partner data systems
overview.implementationTimeline: Year 1 beta pilot, Year 2 full pilot deployment, Year 3 statewide rollout

dataSourceIntegration: Health service HR systems (staffing levels, vacancies, turnover)
Training organisation databases (trainees in region, supervision capacity)
PHN workforce data (primary care workforce, service gaps)
University placement records (students in rural training)
RWAV internal data (recruitment activity, retention programs)
Community survey data (community workforce perceptions, willingness to contribute)
platformFeatures: Real-time workforce dashboard (current staffing, vacancies, trends)
Early warning system (predictive analytics for retention risk, service gaps)
Scenario planning tools (impact modelling of recruitment/retention strategies)
Reporting and analytics (customisable reports, data export)
Mobile accessibility (responsive design for field access)
securityAndPrivacy: Role-based access controls (users see only relevant data for their role)
Data encryption in transit and at rest
Audit logging of all data access and changes
Compliance with health sector privacy standards
Data sharing agreements defining permitted uses
Individual practitioner data aggregated to protect privacy
Regular security audits and penetration testing
interoperabilityStandards: HL7 FHIR for health data exchange
Standard data formats (CSV, JSON, XML) for import/export

developmentMethodology.approach: Agile with 2-week sprints, continuous user feedback, iterative improvement

activities: User research with stakeholders (needs, workflows, pain points)
Data source mapping and integration feasibility
Core platform development (dashboard, data integration, basic analytics)
Beta testing with pilot region users
Deployment to all three pilot regions
Advanced feature development (predictive analytics, scenario planning)
Continuous user support and issue resolution
Ongoing feature enhancement based on user needs
User community development and peer learning

successMetrics: User adoption rate >75% of target users
Early warning system accuracy >80% (predictions vs actual outcomes)
Coordination efficiency: 30% reduction in duplicated recruitment efforts

overview.purpose: Cross-sector partnership for systems reform, resource sharing, and collective advocacy
overview.membership: Health services, PHNs, training organisations, professional colleges, universities, ACCHOs, local government
overview.implementationTimeline: Year 2 establishment, Year 3-5 maturation and impact

activities: Identify potential coalition members and conduct stakeholder analysis
Develop coalition value proposition and benefits case
Conduct individual engagement meetings to gauge interest and commitment
Draft coalition charter defining purpose, governance, participation expectations
Convene inaugural coalition meeting to present charter and seek endorsement
Finalise coalition charter with member input
Establish coalition governance structure (steering committee, working groups)
Develop coalition workplan and priority initiatives
Establish communication protocols and meeting rhythm
Launch first coalition initiative (e.g., joint workforce planning, shared supervision)
Conduct inaugural coalition summit to build relationships and shared vision
Establish working groups for priority areas (policy, data, innovation, cultural safety)
Develop and execute quick wins to demonstrate coalition value
Build coalition brand and external visibility

coalitionFunctions.description: Collaborative regional workforce planning replacing siloed organisational planning
Collective voice for policy reform with greater influence than individual organisations
Pooling resources for efficiency and reach
Rapid spread of best practices and innovations across coalition members

successMetrics: Policy reforms influenced: 2+ with coalition attribution
Resource sharing value: $500k+ annually in shared costs/efficiencies

userRoles.primaryUsers: Health service HR and operations managers

analyticsCapabilities: Descriptive analytics: Current state reporting and trend analysis
Diagnostic analytics: Root cause analysis of workforce challenges
Predictive analytics: Forecasting vacancies, retention risk, service gaps
Prescriptive analytics: Recommended interventions based on data patterns

keyResponsibilities: Overall pilot program management and coordination
Reporting to Board and Transformation Oversight Committee
Local stakeholder liaison and partnership development
Community Map platform configuration and management
Cultural safety framework development and implementation
culturalSafetyAdvisorFirstNationsLiaison.reporting: CEO (with accountability to ACCHO Partnership Council)

additionalRolesYear3.allocation: One per major region for statewide coverage

additionalRolesYear3.purpose: Community Map user support and training

allStaff: Cultural competency and cultural safety understanding

components: Roles and responsibilities of each party
Data sharing protocols and privacy protections
standardMOU.customisations: Tailored for partner type (PHN, health service, training organisation, ACCHO, university)

components: Data to be shared (scope and granularity)

acchoPartnershipAgreement.specialProvisions: ACCHO veto rights on cultural safety matters, community-controlled evaluation mandate

activities: Identify potential partners aligned with RWAV strategy
Assess partner readiness and capacity for collaboration
Initial meetings to explore partnership opportunity
Joint problem definition and shared objectives development
Negotiate roles, responsibilities, and resource contributions
Address concerns and barriers to partnership
Draft partnership agreement with legal review
Finalise partnership agreement with sign-off from authorised signatories
Establish governance structures (steering committees, working groups)
Conduct partnership launch event or communication
Set up operational processes (meetings, reporting, communication)
Regular partnership meetings and progress reviews
Address issues and adapt partnership as needed
Conduct formal partnership review at agreed intervals
Assess partnership value and outcomes achieved
Renew partnership agreement with updated terms
Or gracefully exit partnership if no longer beneficial

principles: Self-determination: ACCHO partners control priorities, methods, and outcomes
Leadership not consultation: ACCHOs lead, RWAV supports
Veto authority: ACCHO partners can veto initiatives affecting Indigenous communities
Community-controlled evaluation: Communities assess cultural safety effectiveness
Resource equity: Adequate resourcing for ACCHO leadership and participation
implementation: ACCHO Partnership Council established with decision-making authority
ACCHO representatives on all relevant governance bodies
ACCHO-led design of all First Nations workforce initiatives
ACCHO approval required before any initiative launch
Regular ACCHO satisfaction assessment and responsive action

culturalSafetyTraining.scope: Mandatory for all RWAV staff, Board members, and partner organisations
content: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander history and culture
Impact of colonisation and ongoing disadvantage
Racism and unconscious bias recognition and management
Practical skills for culturally safe practice
culturalSafetyTraining.delivery: ACCHO-led training with accredited trainers, minimum 2-day program
culturalSafetyTraining.frequency: Initial mandatory training, refresher every 2 years, role-specific additional training
culturalSafetyTraining.accountability: Training completion tracked, performance expectations linked to cultural safety competency

culturalSafetyAudits.process: External independent audit using ACCHO-approved framework
culturalSafetyAudits.outcome: Audit report with recommendations, action plan developed with ACCHO partners

communityFeedback.responsiveness: Feedback reviewed monthly, issues addressed promptly, ACCHO Partnership Council oversight

metrics.baseline: Current % of planning processes with community input

qualitativeIndicators.analysis: ACCHO Partnership Council review, continuous improvement planning

reportingCadence.monthly: Internal operations dashboard for management team
reportingCadence.quarterly: Board reporting pack with KPI progress, risks, milestones
reportingCadence.annual: Comprehensive annual report with outcomes, financials, stakeholder feedback, public release

pilotProgramBudget.totalAllocation: To be determined based on Board approval

year1.expectedReturn: Initial revenue <$100k, primarily proof of concept

immediateActions.description: Secure Board approval for transformation commencement and initial resource allocation
Commence formal partnership negotiations with Bendigo, Gippsland Lakes, and Mallee stakeholders
Issue RFP for Community Map platform development partner
Commence IMG sponsorship services and data intelligence subscriptions pilots
immediateActions.responsibility: CEO and Business Development Manager (to be recruited)

immediateActions.description: Join VHA health collective for sector-level advocacy participation

crossSectorPartnerships.purpose: Address non-workforce barriers (housing, community amenity, family services)
crossSectorPartnerships.approach: Develop formal partnerships with shires in pilot regions, joint planning for community attraction

crossSectorPartnerships.purpose: Support practitioner families with children's education needs
crossSectorPartnerships.approach: Coordinate with school principals, facilitate school transitions, support rural education advocacy

crossSectorPartnerships.purpose: Align health workforce with broader regional development strategies
crossSectorPartnerships.approach: Participate in regional planning forums, integrate health workforce into economic development plans

communitiesOfPractice.purpose: Ongoing peer networking and professional support for rural health workforce
communitiesOfPractice.delivery: Digital platforms (forums, webinars, resource libraries) with periodic face-to-face events
communitiesOfPractice.target: All rural health professionals, specialised groups for specific disciplines/career stages

transparentReporting.commitment: Annual public reporting of transformation progress, outcomes, challenges, and learnings
transparentReporting.format: Annual report published on RWAV website, distributed to stakeholders, presented at sector events
transparentReporting.content: Quantitative outcomes, qualitative stories, financial summary, stakeholder testimonials, lessons learned, year ahead priorities
